_header: Will you hear a good bourd to make you laugh all
_description: ‘The King and the Barker’ — 128 lines in couplets

CULEe435a.First Lines:
Well yow here a god borde to make yow lawhe allhow het ffell apon a
                    tyme er eney man het know…
CULEe435a.Last Lines:
…There owre kyng & the barker partyd ffeyre a twyneGod
                    þat set yn heffene so hey breyng vs owt of sene
CULEe435a.Editions:
Ritson,  Joseph,
                        ed.  
             Pieces of Ancient Popular Poetry.
         London: Clarke, 1791; 2nd ed. 1833: 61-7.
Hazlitt,  William Carew. 
             Remains of the Early Popular Poetry of England.
         London: J. R. Smith, 1864-6: 1.4-10.
Child,  Francis James. 
             The English and Scottish Popular Ballads.
         5 vols. in 10 parts. Boston and New York: Houghton, Mifflin,
            1882-98: 5.78.
